Review Enhancing the performance of platinum group metal-based electrocatalysts through nonmetallic element doping Yiping Li Tanyuan Wang * Zhangyi Yao Qi’an Chen Qing Li * State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology School of Materials Science and Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 China State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China * Corresponding author. * Corresponding author. Platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts have been well recognized as one of the best catalysts towards energy conversion and storage devices, such as fuel cells and water electrolyzers. Nevertheless, their commercial applications are strictly limited by the unsatisfactory catalytic activity and stability. Recently, nonmetallic (H, B, C, N, P, S, etc.) atoms doping is explored to be an efficient strategy to optimize the catalytic activity and durability of PGM-based catalysts via precisely electronic and coordination structure modulation, thus arising tremendous attention. However, systematical discussions on this topic is still lacking. In this review, the representative progresses of nonmetal elements doped PGM-based electrocatalysts for different electrocatalytic reactions are summarized. Firstly, this review discusses the key factors that affect the activity and stability of the catalysts, and introduces the basic principles of nonmetal-doping for improving the performance of PGM-based catalysts. Secondly, advanced characterization techniques and theoretical calculations are highlighted respectively for revealing the activity enhancement mechanism. Then the synthesis methods to incorporate the nonmetals are listed, intending to provide inspirations for the future design of materials. The promising modification strategies for tuning the active species are further proposed. Afterwards, an overview of nonmetal-doped PGM-based catalysts is provided for the electrocatalytic applications, with an emphasis on revealing the structure-performance relationship. Finally, further developments and challenges involving synthesis, mechanism analysis, new materials as well as reactions, stability issues and practical applications are outlined, aiming to promote the in-depth research on advanced PGM-based catalysts. Graphical Abstract This review illustrates the structure-performance relationship of nonmetal doped platinum group metal-based electrocatalysts. The recent achievements are systematically summarized and the general mechanisms including strain/ligand/synergistic effects are revealed. Keywords Electrocatalysis Nonmetal doping Platinum group metal-based catalyst Oxygen reduction Hydrogen evolution 1 Introduction Global warming and energy crisis caused by the excessive use of fossil fuels have led to unsustainable development of the world ecology and threatened the survival of humanity [ 1–5 ]. It is imminent to replace fossil fuels with clean renewable energy and accomplish energy structure transformation. Hydrogen energy devices, such as electrochemical water splitting devices and fuel cells, are recognized as one of the most promising energy storage/conversion devices owing to their tremendous advantages in sustainability, energy density and conversion efficiency [ 6,7 ]. Electrocatalysts, which aim to accelerate electrochemical reaction kinetics on the electrode/electrolyte interface, govern the performance of the electrochemical devices and thus have been the focus of the electrocatalysis community over the past few years. Among the various catalysts, platinum group metal (PGM) materials (such as Pt, Pd, and Ru) are the most used catalysts towards electrochemical reactions because of their better catalytic performance compared with non-noble or non-metal catalysts [ 8–13 ]. It is reported that PGM catalysts account for more than 70% of the global heterogeneous catalyst market and are integral parts for the development of renewable energy storage/conversion device [ 14 ]. Unfortunately, the commercial PGM catalysts still suffer from insufficient activity and stability in electrocatalysis, largely inhibiting their potential applications in hydrogen energy devices. Taking commercial carbon supported platinum catalyst (Pt/C) in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) as an example, its mass activity (MA) is 0.1–0.2 A mgPt –1 for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), much lower than the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) 2025 target (MA is 0.44 A mgPt –1). Moreover, under PEMFC operating conditions (high voltage, strong acid environment and large current), Pt/C catalyst undergoes severe durability issues and the corresponding MA attenuation exceeds 60% after 30000 cycle durability tests between 0.6–0.95 V, while the target set by DOE is less than 40% MA loss [ 15–17 ]. To better meet the exacting performance targets, many strategies have been conducted, such as alloying PGMs with other elements [ 18,19 ], phase engineering [ 20,21 ], preparing single atom catalysts [ 22,23 ] and manipulating particle size [ 24,25 ] or morphology [ 26,27 ]. Among all the proposed strategies, element doping may be the most efficient method to develop advanced electrochemical catalysts [ 28–30 ]. It can effectively modify the electronic structure of the active sites to optimize the catalytic performance and has great structural and compositional flexibility [ 31,32 ]. The doping effect can be well controlled by adjusting the type, position and concentration of the dopants. Compared with the commonly reported metallic element doping, introducing nonmetal dopants shows different properties and thus has drawn increasing attention. Firstly, nonmetals can enter the interstitial sites of the PGMs because of their smaller radii, providing more possibilities for regulating strain effect and electronic structure of PGMs [ 33 ]. Secondly, the doped nonmetals would induce strong charge transfer and generate s, p-d hybridization with the host metals, which is different from the d-d orbital coupling in the metal-metal alloys [ 34 ]. Thirdly, nonmetal-doped PGM catalysts could exhibit outstanding durability due to the robust nonmetal-metal bond [ 35 ]. Up to present, nonmetallic elements including boron (B) [ 30,36–39 ], nitrogen (N) [ 40–42 ], phosphorous (P) [ 43,44 ], carbon (C) [ 45 ], hydrogen (H) [ 46–49 ] and sulfur (S) [ 50,51 ] have been successfully doped into PGM-based catalysts (Fig. 1 ). Although there are some progresses in nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts, systemic studies are deficient. Currently, most of the reviews for PGM-based catalysts mainly focus on transition metal incorporated PGM-based catalysts [ 52–54 ]. In this review, recent achievements in nonmetallic atom doped PGM-based catalysts toward various electrocatalytic reactions and devices are summarized. Firstly, we elaborate on the factors that affect the activity and stability of catalysts, as well as the possible mechanism of non-metallic doping in tuning the electrocatalytic performance of PGM-based catalysts. Secondly, the operando characterization techniques and supplement theoretical calculations are introduced for in-depth mechanism analysis. Thirdly, the synthetic strategies are listed, which are the foundation of the next step of the reaction. Afterwards, the promising and advanced modification strategy are proposed, extending to facilitate the inspiration of further research. Then we discuss the applications of nonmetal-doped PGM-based catalysts in electrocatalytic reactions, including ORR, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) and oxidation of liquid small molecules. Finally, challenges and opportunities for this class of electrocatalytic materials are proposed, aiming to offer inspiration for the further research. This review not only covers the processes of nonmetal-doped PGM-based catalysts from synthesis to electrocatalytic application, but also reveals the catalytic mechanism and the structure-performance relationship of PGM-based materials with nonmetal doping, which would contribute to the understanding on catalysis, nanomaterials synthesis, electrochemistry and energy science. 2 Possible effects of nonmetal doping on PGM-based electrocatalysts 2.1 The influence of nonmetal doping on the activity of PGM-based catalysts The intrinsic activity of catalyst is highly related to the adsorption properties of reactant species on active sites. Based on the widely accepted Sabatier principle, the interaction between the active sites and adsorbed reactants/intermediates should be moderate to achieve the balance of adsorption and desorption processes, so as to achieve the optimal catalytic activity [ 55,56 ]. Many researches show that the d-band center (ε d) proposed by Nørskov et al. [ 18,57,58 ] is a widely employed descriptor for the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates on PGMs. Specifically, the upshift of ε d relative to the Fermi level will lead to the enhanced adsorption of reaction intermediates, and the downshift of ε d results in the opposite effect. Due to the discrepancies in electronegativity and atomic radii between nonmetal atoms and PGM atoms as well as the possible orbital hybridization, nonmetallic element doping strategy becomes an effective approach to regulate the ε d value of PGMs through strain and ligand effects [ 59,60 ]. Moreover, microstrain that originates from structural defects (grain boundaries, atomic vacancies and stacking dislocations) can also be introduced by nonmetal doping, thus producing some catalytic sites with close-to-optimal structural configuration [ 61 ]. Besides, nonmetals are favorable for the adsorption of certain reaction intermediates such as OH and can act as additional active sites, improving the activity of the catalysts through synergistic effect [ 62 ]. In the following section, we will discuss the effects of nonmetal doping on the activity of PGM-based catalysts from the perspective of above-mentioned four mechanisms respectively. Strain effect, where strain is usually referred as global strain or macrostrain, is originated from lattice mismatch between the doped nonmetal atoms and the solvent metals. It can effectively regulate the ε d value of the surface active sites and therefore influence the catalytic activity. For PGMs with more than half-filled d bands, tensile strain (presented as enlarged interatomic distance) brings in narrowed overlap of d states between neighboring metal atoms and corresponding decreased d-band width. It leads to the upshift of ε d in order to maintain the fixed d occupancy. On the contrary, compressive strain (reflected in decreased lattice constant) of PGMs will lead to the downshift of ε d (Fig. 2(a) ) [ 63 ]. Regarding to the site modification of the host unit cell, nonmetal doping can be divided into substitutional and interstitial doping mechanisms. In these two doping systems, nonmetals are located at different positions in the lattice of PGMs, leading to distinct lattice mismatch and therefore discrepancy in the modulation of ε d. For substitutional doping system, where nonmetallic atoms replace part of atoms in the host lattice, the lattice mismatch originates from the radii difference between solute nonmetal and solvent metal atoms. Since the radii of nonmetallic atoms are generally smaller than those of PGM atoms, compressive strain is introduced and the correspondingly ε d shifts down [ 64 ]. But for interstitial solid solution systems, nonmetal solute atoms mostly tend to distribute in the largest interstitial sites of the host lattice, which are the octahedral sites (O-site) for face-center-cubic (FCC), hexagonal-close-packed (HCP) and body-center-cubic (BCC) structures along <110> direction [ 46,65 ]. The lattice mismatch is due to the discrepancy between solute atoms and solvent interstitial void sites [ 66 ]. The solute atoms are mostly larger than the interstitial voids, expanding the lattice of host atoms and eventually achieving the upshift of ε d [ 40,67 ]. It is noteworthy that for light elements with atomic radii less than 60% of PGM atoms, such as H and B, they tend to diffuse into PGM lattice interstitial sites rather than replacing metal atoms [ 68 ]. However, P and S atoms with relatively larger radii can either occupy the interstitial lattice sites or substitute host atoms [ 69,70 ]. As a result, nonmetal doping offers great potential for precisely modulating the strain of PGMs to attain expected electrocatalytic activity. In addition to the global strain discussed above, incorporating nonmetal atoms into PGMs will also bring in microstrain, which is generated from structural defects such as grain boundaries, atomic vacancies and stacking dislocations as a result of doping. The term ‘microstrain’ is used to quantify the local deviations of the atoms from their ideal positions in the crystal structure. It will cause peak broadening of the synchrotron wide-angle X-ray scattering characterization (WAXS) rather than changing the peak position, which is different from the as-mentioned macrostrain (Fig. 2(b)) [ 71 ]. Nonmetallic doping has been proven to induce lattice distortion in PGM crystal structures, possibly resulting in localized or totally amorphous features [ 72,73 ]. For instance, Wang et al. [ 74 ] found that incorporating S into crystalline Pd resulted in the rapid expansion of the lattice of Pd and thus prevents the atomic arrangement of the Pd from remaining FCC structure. Therefore, the crystalline region partially transforms to an amorphous region, leading to the generation of microstrain. The degree of lattice distortion increases along with the improved doping concentration, and interstitial atoms will bring in larger microstrain than substitutional atoms when being doped at equal concentrations [ 75,76 ]. Importantly, despite that both strain effects and microstrain can enhance the catalytic activity of PGM-based electrocatalysts if rationally designed, they operate on different aspects. The strain effect would tune the electronic structures of all surface active sites. However, microstrain tends to create a wide range of specific catalytic sites, thus promoting the reaction [ 77 ]. For example, the introduced microstrain with the doping of nonmetal atoms can produce more unsaturated coordination atoms and dangling bonds, leading to abundant adsorption sites with high catalytic activity [ 78 ]. Ligand effect originates from the change of the chemical environment for the host surface atoms, which is mostly caused by the specific chemical properties of foreign atoms. Generally speaking, if PGMs obtain electrons, the occupancy of their d state will concomitantly exaggerate, leading to a downshift of the d-band center. Conversely, the diminished occupancy of d state for PGMs when losing electrons causes an upshift of the d-band center. When incorporating nonmetal atoms into host materials, it will inevitably lead to partial electron transfer and s, p-d orbital hybridization between two different neighboring atoms. Such charge transfer and hybridization will alter the ε d of PGMs relative to Fermi level and the consequent catalytic activity (Fig. 2(c)) [ 51,79 ]. Theoretically, the shift degree and direction of ε d are largely influenced by the spatial distribution and concentration of nonmetal atoms in the host lattice of PGMs. Taking Pd for an example, Zou et al. [ 34 ] found that the subsurface B led to a large downshifted d-band center on surface Pd atoms (about 0.4 eV), while the deeper B layers had little influence on the d-band center of surface Pd atoms. Besides, along with the increase of subsurface B concentration, the surface d-band center becomes more negative relative to Fermi level, attributing to the stronger s, p-d orbital hybridization between Pd and B atoms. The difference in electronegativity between nonmetallic and metal atoms also plays an important role in the shift of ε d. N, C and S with much higher electronegativity are prone to polarize the surrounding atoms and thus are more likely to cause an apparent increase in the ε d of active sites [ 80,81 ]. Recent study shows N atoms exert an obvious electron-withdrawing effect on the Ru atoms for two-dimensional porphyrin-based Ru-N coordination polymers on nanocarbon support, giving rise to the reinforced binding energy of Ru to H and OH [ 82 ]. For H, B and P, controversies still exist for the electron transfer direction between PGMs and nonmetals due to their similar electronegativity [ 83–85 ]. For example, Wang et al. [ 86 ] suggest that 0.4 electron transfers from each B atom to surrounding Pd atoms, confirmed by Bader charge analysis. However, the opposite charge transfer direction is also reported by other Pd-B catalysts [ 39,87 ]. It may originate from different local coordination environment and computational models. Another mechanism that affects the catalytic activity of PGMs with nonmetal doping is the synergistic effect, where the nonmetal atoms can act as the second active sites (Fig. 2(d)). For example, oxyphilic nonmetal atoms can adsorb *OH during oxidation of liquid small molecules in alkaline environments, thereby promoting the removal of *CO intermediate on PGM sites and improving the reaction activity [ 88–91 ]. In addition, if the introduced nonmetal element is negatively charged after charge transfer, it can more easily attract positively charged reactants and facilitate the reaction kinetics [ 85,92 ]. 2.2 Improved stability of nonmetal-doped PGM-based electrocatalysts The stability of the electrocatalyst is also a critical issue in the practical implementation, especially during long-term operations. Many researches show that the harsh operating conditions of practical devices will result in metal dissolution, particle agglomeration and Oswald ripening, leading to performance decay [ 93–97 ]. Alloying PGMs with nonprecious metals is an efficient way to improve the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts, but these nonprecious metals still suffer from corrosion issues under typical working conditions [ 98,99 ]. On the contrary, nonmetal doping can effectively improve the stability of catalysts due to their high corrosion resistance and strong interaction with metals [ 100 ]. According to Gibbs-Thomson equation as followed, the binding energy of the dissolved atoms with surrounding atoms (E b) and the overall cohesion energy (E coh) have a prominent impact on the dissolution potential (U diss) of the atoms [ 101 ]. (1) U d i s s 1 = U d i s s b u l k + E b - E c o h b u l k 2 e (2) U d i s s a l l = U d i s s b u l k + E c o h - E c o h b u l k 2 e where E coh refers to the energy required by condensed matter to eliminate the force of intermolecular interaction, positively correlated with metal–metal (M–M) bond strength. The more positive E coh, the higher dissolution potential value. Similarly, Speak et al. [ 102 ] demonstrated that the dissolution amount of metals during the oxide formation process had a negative correlation with the cohesive energy (Fig. 3(a) ). That is, metals with higher cohesive energy have stronger bond strength and are less inclined to dissolve. Therefore, introducing nonmetals can effectively restrain the metal dissolution through forming strong nonmetal-metal bonds [ 42,103,104 ]. Li et al. [ 105 ] calculated the bond energy of metal-metal and metal-carbon with density functional theory (DFT) and found that metal-carbon bonds are 1.4–2.0 times stronger than the metal-metal bonds. Therefore, as the interstitial carbon content increases, the bond energy of the alloy system becomes stronger (Fig. 3(b)), thus decreasing both alloy passivity and metal dissolution rate. Moreover, other nonmetals such as S and N are also reported to form strong covalent or ionic bonds with metals, thus can improve the anti-corrosion ability of materials [ 106,107 ]. In this regard, nonmetal doping would offer great opportunities to enhance the stability of the catalysts for practical applications. During the electrochemical testing process, PGMs may be oxidized to form stable oxides if the applied potential exceeds their dissolution potential. Since PGMs would be more easily dissolved during the reduction of their oxides, the dissolution rate is closely related to the M–O interaction [ 108,109 ]. The surface chemisorbed oxygen will extract noble metal atoms from the surface of the catalysts and subsequently free these atoms from the constraints of surface lattices, thus destabilizing the catalysts [ 110 ]. Nonmetal doping has already been reported to decrease the PGM–O interaction through metal-support or electronic interaction [ 42,103 ]. Moreover, the doping of nonmetals can also inhibit the dissolution of non-noble metals in PGM-based alloys by tuning their work function [ 111 ]. Work function (Φ) is the minimum energy when extracting an electron at Fermi level from metal inner to vacuum [ 112 ]. It is highly related to dissolution current (I) and the correlation is as followed [ 101 ]: (3) I = I 0 { exp [ ∝ nF ( U - Φ + Δ Φ e ) R T - exp [ - ( 1 - ∝ ) nF ( U - Φ + Δ Φ e ) R T } It is clear that a higher work function leads to a much-decreased dissolution manner and thus results in higher stability. Besides, Li et al. [ 113 ] discovered that there is a positive linear relationship between work function and dissolution potential (Fig. 4(a) ). A larger work function corresponds to more stable electron state, in other words, higher dissolution resistance [ 114 ]. A small amount of nonmetallic doping can effectively increase the work function of metals and some researchers attribute the higher work function to the hybridization between the p orbital of nonmetal atoms and the d orbitals of metal atoms [ 115,116 ]. For example, it is reported that the work function of steel linearly increases with increasing interstitial carbon content (Fig. 4(b)). When C content reaches to 0.88% (mass weight), the corresponding work function increases about 0.6 eV [ 116 ]. Therefore, the corrosion rates of steel clearly decrease with the doping of carbon, confirming that the presence of interstitial carbon improves the corrosion resistance of metals. However, it is worth noting that although the incorporation of nonmetals is beneficial for enhancing the stability of the catalysts, nonmetals will also be oxidized and dissolve, thereby leading to potential performance degradation [ 117 ]. Based on their characteristics, the advantages and disadvantages of each nonmetallic element are summarized in Table 1 . 3 Advanced characterization techniques for unraveling the effects caused by nonmetal doping Characterizing the coordinate and structure change of PGMs after nonmetal modification from local and global aspects is crucial to unveil the structure-activity relationships and related mechanism. The traditional characterizations rely on the X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [ 118 ] and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) etc. With the development of science and technology, some advanced representations such as in-situ Fourier transform infrared [ 119 ] and electrochemical scanning tunneling microscopy [ 120 ] gradually occupy the historical stage. They have been developed to understand the nonmetal effects on PGMs. For example, in-situ characterization could provide abundant information including oxidation state, local coordination, structural reconstruction, vibrational information, and morphological evolution of nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts in real-time during the reaction [ 121 ]. In addition, they can achieve the dynamic detection of the intermediates as well as the products, which facilitates the mechanism research [ 122 ]. In this section, we will introduce two aspects: advanced imaging technology and in-situ characterization. 3.1 Advanced imaging technology for the direct detection of nonmetals Currently, the most commonly applied imaging technologies are TEM [ 123 ], atomic force microscope [ 124 ] and X-ray domputed tomogram [ 125 ], etc. Although the image contrast quantification of these techniques can theoretically identify all types of atoms, the low content as well as small atomic of nonmetals result in the poor imaging ability and the difficulty to directly visualize nonmetallic atoms. As a result, new advanced imaging techniques have attracted a lot of attention in recent years. Integrated/differentiated differential phase contrast scanning transmission electron microscope (iDPC/dDPC STEM) is a recently-developed phase imaging technique based on the center of mass movement of convergent electron beam diffraction patterns. For very thin samples, the iDPC and the dDPC are linear in the projected electrostatic potential and the charge density distribution, respectively. As a result, nonmetal elements can be visible. The capability of the iDPC and dDPC STEM technique in direct imaging light elements such as hydrogen has been demonstrated by recent theoretical and experimental results (Fig. 5(a) ) [ 46 ]. The same purpose can be achieved by ptychography, a newly emerging functional phase imaging technology which is highly sensitive to some nonmetal elements. For example, the ptychography image can not only observe the B element in the Pd-B structure, but also certify that these B atoms are at the octahedral position of the Pd lattice by fitting with the theoretical model (Fig. 5(b)) [ 126 ]. 3.2 In-situ characterizations based on X-ray or vibrational spectroscopy In-situ synchrotron X-rays, neutron diffraction and X-ray pair distribution function (XPDF) show high applicability to obtain the information about the influence of nonmetals on the parent metal structure. They can reveal the evolution of nonmetals in electrochemical testing and thus are favorable for the revealing of catalytic mechanism. Compared with non in-situ characterization techniques, the operando techniques show profound superiority. For example, Chen et al. [ 126 ] used in-situ XPDF to reveal the thermal stability of Pd-B. As the temperature increased from room temperature to 216 °C, the lattice constant of Pd-B gradually decreased, suggesting the thermally driven exclusion of the interstitial B atoms from the Pd lattice (Fig. 6(a) ). And Song et al. [ 127 ] found that Pd phase gradually transformed to PdH x when H2 was introduced while the PdH x phase reverted back to the Pd phase when exposed in the hydrogen deficient environment. (Fig. 6(b)). However, it is worth noting that these in-situ structural characterization techniques cannot reflect all the details. For example, when B is introduced, it may cause a slight transition for Pd from FCC phase to HCP phase. However, in XPDF cards, HCP phase cannot be observed due to its small proportion. Therefore, more accurate structural characterization are needed to reveal the structural information of the material. At the same time, some in-situ structural characterization techniques in electrochemical testing are also urgently demanded. Operando spectroscopic techniques are also used to study nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts. In-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) is a powerful tool to provide structural and chemical information for a catalytical system [ 128 ]. It can roughly divide into X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) region and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) region according to the incident X-ray energy. In the low energy region, in-situ XANES can be applied to unveil the variation of oxidation state, molecular orbitals, chemical species and electronic state for a specific element. Meanwhile, in the high energy region, operando EXAFS provides the local geometric structure transform information including the coordination number and interatomic distance around the probed atoms. For example, the decreased white-light intensity in XANES (Fig. 7(a) ) and intensity of Os-OH in EXAFS (Fig. 7(b)) for B doped Os HER catalysts are observed with the decrease of the applied potential [ 129 ]. Therefore, Li et al. [ 129 ] demonstrated that in the alkaline environment, the B-Os aerogels underwent reduction to adapt the OH species to bond on the catalyst surface and further bond with H* through the Volmer-Heyrovsky step. On the other hand, the detection and monitoring of intermediates and products during reaction process are of great importance for reaction mechanism research, especially for the reactions which involves various intermediates. The mostly used in-situ characterizations include Raman, attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy spectra [ 130 ]. They can clearly reveal the intermediates of materials. For example, the change of characteristic peaks of *OH along with potentials indicates that OH participates in the reaction and thus the beneficial role of nonmetals in promoting OH adsorption is emphasized. 4 Theoretical calculations for revealing the catalytic mechanism In addition to the advanced experimental characterization, theoretical calculations are inevitable for unlocking the performance enhancement mechanisms induced by nonmetal incorporation. Currently the most commonly used method is DFT. Considering the types, concentrations and positions of nonmetals in PGM lattice, the most reasonable and stable theoretical model is constructed to identify the true active sites and reaction pathways (Fig. 8(a) ), as well as reveal the influence of nonmetals on the electronic properties of PGM materials [ 131 ]. For the former, the predictions for active sites and catalytic activity can be realized by calculating the adsorption energy of key reaction intermediates and reaction energy barrier. For example, for ORR and HER, ΔG O* and ΔG H* are the widely applied activity descriptors respectively. When these two values reach their optimal value, the highest activity is possibly achieved. In addition, the reaction step with the highest energy barrier is the rate-determining step (RDS). Effectively reducing the energy barrier of RDS is an important reason for nonmetallic doping to improve the activity. For example, DFT results reveal that the RDS of HER/HOR for Rh is the hydroxide adsorption step, with the energy barrier of 0.62 eV. And it changes to the water desorption step on P-Rh/C catalysts and the corresponding energy barrier decreases to 0.4 eV compare with undoped ones (Fig. 8(b)) [ 132 ]. Therefore, P-Rh shows enhanced HOR activity, attributing to the relatively lower energy barrier. For the latter, DFT can determine the charge transfer between nonmetals and PGMs through Bader charge analysis, as well as analyze the bonding properties by electron localization function and crystal orbital Hamilton populations. It is worth noting that there are also dynamic theoretical calculations such as molecular dynamic simulations in addition to the above-mentioned static DFT calculations [ 133 ]. They can further contribute to the understanding on the reaction mechanisms and the changes of molecules/atoms in the electrocatalytic process. For example, molecular dynamic simulations can compute electron-electron interactions explicitly by solving the intermolecular interaction potential function and motion equation. Therefore, through analyzing the behavior of molecular motion they are capable of describing the forces on atoms along catalyzed reaction pathways in heterogeneous systems and simulating the dynamic evolution process of the system [ 134 ]. 5 General synthesis strategy for incorporating non-metals into the lattice of PGMs As mentioned above, the performance of PGM-based catalysts is largely influenced by the spatial distribution, type and concentration of nonmetal atoms. It is quite important to obtain well-defined nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts for efficient electrocatalysis. Therefore, refined synthesis strategy is urgently demanded. Up to now, a large number of experimental methods have been reported with the aiming to obtain nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts with optimal adsorption for intermediates. The design approaches can be divided to four aspects: chemical vapor deposition, high-temperature pyrolysis process, wet chemical reduction and electrochemical-concerning method (Fig. 9 ). In the following section, these four preparations will be discussed. 5.1 Chemical vapor deposition The incorporation of nonmetal elements into PGM can be obtained by treating PGM precursors under nonmetal-containing atmospheres with a certain temperature and pressure. It is well admitted that during the nonmetal doping process, nonmetallic resource gas will adsorb on the solid power surface, followed by dissociation and diffusion into the PGMs lattice. In the chemical vapor deposition method, various parameters including temperature, gas flow rate, pressure, type of nonmetal gas etc. have effects on the final results [ 135 ]. Importantly, the nonmetals can achieve effective transformation from surface to the bulk materials driven by increased temperature and pressure. It offers brilliant potential for the fine regulation of PGM-based catalysts. Notably, higher pressure and temperature is needed to achieve higher nonmetal loading (Fig. 10(a) ). Therefore, specialized laboratory facilities are demanded, making it difficult in large-scale application [ 136 ]. Moreover, when the temperature is high enough, the nonmetals will probably escape and generate abundant vacancies [ 137 ]. 5.2 High-temperature pyrolysis High-temperature pyrolysis synthesis is an efficient method to combine PGMs with nonmetals. It refers calcining metallic and non-metallic mixtures (e.g. B and P) under an inert atmosphere (Fig. 10(b)) [ 29 ]. The as-obtained materials are usually in possession of few defects, high crystallinity and stability. Besides, it usually loads on a high specific area support, and cover with rather thin carbon layers in the surface, facilitating the catalytic performance [ 138 ]. The most considered drawback is the difficulty to prepare the desired materials with controllable morphology and size due to easier atomic migration at high temperatures. However, attempts have been made to synthesis the ultra-small nanoparticles by carefully selecting nonmetallic source precursors. For example, Liu et al. [ 51 ] used a multifunctional highly cross-linked polymer poly (yclotriphosphazene-co-4,4’-sulfonyldiphenol, PZS) with abundant N=P, S=O bonds and functional groups to synthesize ultrafine S-doped RuP nanoparticles. The PZS bonds with the metal ions and limits the abnormal growth of nanoparticles. Therefore, particle sizes with less than 4 nm can be achieved even under high calcination temperature calcination at 900 °C. 5.3 Wet chemical reduction Due to the mild reaction condition and flexible preparation routes, wet chemical reduction approach has been widely considered to be the most applied methods (Fig. 10(c)) [ 139 ]. It can be divided into solvothermal method and hydrothermal method based on the type of solvent. Because of the formation of trace organic oxide, the former generally is accompanied by the passivation of catalyst surface, implying effusion suppression of nonmetals [ 140 ]. It endows nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts with excellent stability to some extent. The latter can produce catalysts with a cleaner surface and is beneficial for exposing more active sites. A large number of nonmetal-containing reagent have been applied to prepare nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts and the selection is nonnegligible. At present, the reagents used as efficient nonmetal dopants in solution include H source (e.g., N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) [ 47 ], formaldehyde [ 141 ], ethanol [ 49 ]), B source (generally including dimethylamine borane (DMAB) [ 30 ], and NaBH4 [ 142 ]), C containing agents (such as glucose [ 45 ]), N reagents (such as urea [ 67 ]), P containing reagents (e.g. NaH2PO2 [ 85 ], P powder [ 62 ] and tri-octyl phosphine oxide (TOPO) [ 143 ]), and S containing reagents (such as Na2S [ 74 ]). 5.4 Electrochemical methods Electrochemical methods can be divided into two aspects. On the one hand, the reactant gas (including H2, NH3, and alkynes) may adsorb on the metal surface during operation of electrocatalytic reaction, and further diffuse into the metal lattice. For example, Song et al. [ 127 ] demonstrated that Pd interlayer in Au@Pd x @Ru could transiently store hydrogen enriched at the interface in the low potential range to form PdH x , and the stored hydrogen spontaneously overflowed in the high potential range of HOR (Fig. 10(d)). Through applying modest potential, non-metallic doping can be achieved, which is generally suitable for the preparation of PdH x . Compared with gas-based method, electrochemical H-insert method can achieve higher H loading (H/Pd ratio > 0.7) in an ambient pressure and temperature. However, it is limited by the insufficient ability for preparing materials with controllable size and morphology. Moreover, hydrogenated state is not stable once the electrochemical potential is removed. 6 Promising modification strategy for tuning the active species 6.1 Stabilizing the amalgamation of PGMs with other metals According to phase diagram, some elements are immiscible. However, researches have shown that nonmetals are beneficial for reducing their formation enthalpy of alloying and make it possible to prepare miscible alloys. Therefore, electrocatalytic activity of these alloys can be investigated. For example, it has been a challenge to synthesize Ag-based nanoparticles as electrocatalysts because Ag hardly solubilizes transition metals. Nonmetal element P can help the amalgamation of Ag with other metals, and Ag-Ni-Fe-P nanoparticles are successfully synthesized by a one-pot solution-phase chemistry (Fig. 11(a) ) [ 144 ]. Without P, only segregated irregular Ag and NiFe nanoparticles can be obtained. The obtained Ag-Ni-Fe-P catalysts show both high ORR and OER activities, attributing to the multielement composition and the synergistic effects between the different elements (Figs. 11(b), (c)). And it is also proven that H stabilizes the RhPd bimetallene, which shows a very large miscibility gap phase diagram (Fig. 11(d)) [ 141 ]. The formation of the RhPdH is ascribed to Miedema rule of reverse stability in combination with electronic structure effects, specifically band filling (Fig. 11(e)). The obtained RhPdH catalysts exhibit outstanding alkaline HER catalytic performance with a low overpotential of 40 mV at 10 mA cm–2. 6.2 Heterojunction construction Recently heterojunction catalysts have attracted much attention in the emerging advanced materials [ 145,146 ]. They often show a better catalytic activity than the single-component catalysts. The reasons are listed as followed. Firstly, the lattice strain in the heterojunction interface can expose more unsaturated active sites, facilitating the optimization for the adsorption energy of intermediates. Secondly, heterogeneous interfaces are conducive to charge redistribution, creating built-in electric field and space-charge regions. They can further optimize charge transfer and interface polarization. The addition of non-metals has great advantages in constructing heterogeneous interfaces. It can not only induce phase transition, such as the transition of Pd from FCC to HCP with the increasing of B content, but also transform the crystalline state into an amorphous state. The heterogeneous interfaces are accordingly formed and improve the electrocatalytic activity at the interface. Deng et al. [ 147 ] prepared amorphous/crystalline hetero-phase RuB aerogel (a/c-RuB aerogel) and manipulated the proportion of amorphous and crystalline interfaces by regulating the amount of doped B. The interconnection interface with amorphous/crystalline heterostructures is clearly observed through HRTEM (Fig. 12(a) ). The charge transfer resistance of a/c-RuB aerogel obtained through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy testing is significantly lower than that of crystalline Ru-B and amorphous Ru-B (Fig. 12(b)). It confirms that the heterojunction interface resulted by B doping favors fast charge transfer. Another form of heterojunction arises from the metal-support interaction. In the heterogeneous field, metal-support interaction can be largely applied to regulate the electronic structure of active species, thereby optimizing the activity and stability of electrocatalysts [ 148 ]. The nonmetals doping strategy is an effective means for activating metal-support interaction between support and PGM-based catalysts. Ma et al. [ 149 ] demonstrated that the interstitial C doping resulted in electronic metal-support interactions structures in Pt catalyst, promoting the electron transfer from Pt to interstitial C and gathering the delocalized electrons. Therefore, the interstitial C atoms worked as electron shuttles to achieve effective modulation of key intermediates to improve catalytic performance. Similarly, Yu et al. [ 138 ] proposed that B doping activated and enhanced strong metal-support interaction between Rh nanoparticles and N-doped graphitic carbon matrix (NC) support. Compared with Rh@NC, Rh in the as-obtained B-Rh@NC loses more electrons. It causes the charge redistribution and accelerates electron delocalization, confirmed by electronic local function (ELF) (Fig. 12(c)). Therefore, B-Rh@NC possesses the optimal ΔG H* and enhanced performance. In likewise, introduction of Mo and P induces significant electron transfer from P-doped porous carbon (PC) to P,Mo-Ru cluster (Fig. 12(d)), and the charge is further transferred from Ru atom to Mo and P atom (Fig. 13(e) ) [ 29 ]. It results in the higher valence states of Ru, greatly reducing the water dissociation barrier and improving alkaline HER activity. 7 Electrocatalytic application of nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts 7.1 Oxygen reduction reaction The performance of PEMFCs and metal-air batteries are primarily limited by the sluggish kinetics of the cathodic ORR. During multistep four-electron transfer processes of ORR (Fig. 13), three key oxygen-containing intermediates (*O/*OH/ *OOH) may emerge and the adsorption energy of them (referred to as ΔG O, ΔG OH and ΔG OOH respectively) can be served as reactivity descriptor [ 150,151 ]. According to the ORR activity-ΔG O volcano plot proposed by Nørskov and co-workers [ 152 ], Pt is closed to the top of volcano plot among all monometal catalysts. However, the adsorption of *O on Pt surface is still a little too strong, which requires further optimization [ 151 ]. Moreover, the stability issue is also urgent to be solved [ 153 ]. The activity of Pt-based catalyst can be improved by weakening the binding strength between Pt and oxygen-containing intermediates, indicating the lower ε d. As discussed in Section 2, nonmetal doping into noble metals can alter their electronic structure and the dissolution behavior, which would benefit the ORR catalysts. In the following section, we will discuss and summarize some recent advances of nonmetal doped catalysts for ORR (Table 2 ). P is a highly researched dopant for Pt-based catalysts. Lu et al. [ 154 ] demonstrated that doping P atoms in Pt nanoparticles could result in lattice distortion of Pt and introduce microstrain because of their surface doping nature and much shorter Pt–P bond distance (2.26 Å) than the Pt–Pt bond (2.81 Å). The presence of subsurface P atoms causes the reconstruction of Pt surface and thus produces some concave Pt sites closest to P. DFT calculations show that the surface Pt atom in site 4 is ∼0.9 Å under the Pt in site 3 (Fig. 14(a) ). As a result, the *OH binding energy of Pt atom in site 4 is weakened and close to the optimal value (Fig. 14(b)), leading to increased ORR activity. The as-obtained catalyst exhibits excellent MA of 1.00 A mgPt –1 and retained 86% of the initial MA after 10000 cycles as well as high power density of 1.06 W cm–2 under H2-air conditions (Fig. 14(c)), much better than the commercial Pt/C. The authors ascribe the enhanced stability to the inhibited Oswald ripening and migration of nanoparticles due to P doping. Phosphorus doping strategy can also be applied to Pt-M alloys, such as Pt2Ni concave octahedral catalysts [ 155 ]. The P-doped Pt2Ni concave octahedral nanoparticles show about 2- and 10-times specific activity enhancement for ORR compared to PtNi and commercial Pt/C catalysts in the alkaline electrolyte respectively. Apart from the microstrain induced by P doping, recent studies demonstrated that interstitial N-doping induced tensile-strain can also be beneficial for the ORR activity of PtM intermetallic catalysts. It is found that the lattice strain in intermetallic Pt-Ni (Int-PtNi) is overcompressed, leading to too weak Pt-O adsorption. The interstitial N doping in Int-PtNi can alleviate the high lattice contraction, bringing in the optimum adsorption strength and enhanced ORR activity [ 40 ]. The corresponding intermetallic PtNiN/Ketjenblack (KB) catalyst exhibits SA and MA of 2.92 mA cm–2 and 1.83 A mgPt –1 at 0.9 V for ORR, respectively, far outperforming commercial Pt/C and intermetallic PtNi/KB catalyst. The Int-PtNiN/KB also shows good stability for ORR during long-term cycling as a result of the intermetallic structure and the strong Ni4–N bonds between N and Ni atoms (Fig. 14(d)). The MA loss of Int-PtNiN/KB after the ADT in fuel cell is 35%, meeting the DOE requirement (< 40%). The enhanced stability due to N doping is also applicable to disorder PtCo/C catalyst. But it should be noted that the doped N content is not provided. Lee et al. [ 136 ] found that high N concentration promoted the segregation of Pt and in turn facilitated the diffusion of Pt atoms to the vacant sites of the outermost shell, preventing the Co core from dissolution. Benefiting from the segregated Pt shell, the Pt40Co36N24/C catalyst exhibits an ORR activity retention of 80% after 180000 cycles and maintains the core-shell structure even after 1000000 cycles of accelerated stress tests. However, for pure Pt catalyst, both the interstitial doping and the strong electronegativity of N are unfavorable for its ORR activity. Different from N doping, introducing B element with fortius electron donating ability makes it possible to obtain augmented ORR activity, which can be ascribed to the strong ligand effect [ 30 ]. As the charge transferring from B to Pt atoms, the d-band center for the B-doped Pt (111) surface shifts down by 0.2 and 0.6 eV compared with the undoped Pt (111) surface for the B coverage of 0.25 monolayer and 0.75 monolayer, respectively. Besides, the oxidation state of Pt atoms adjacent to B atoms is less than +0.44 (Fig. 15(a) ), lower than that of Pt atoms in undoped Pt (111) (+0.67), thus hindering the extraction of surface Pt atoms. In PEMFC test, the maximum output power of the B doped Pt/C is 1.24 W cm–2, higher than the counterpart for commercial Pt/C. Meanwhile, the B doped Pt/C shows only 15% performance loss after 30000 cycles at H2-O2 single cell tests, far exceeding commercial Pt/C (Fig. 15(b)). In the activity –ΔG O volcano plot, Pd is close to Pt. Even though its strong adsorption with oxygen-containing intermediates and potential dissolution under acid condition limit its application in PEMFCs, it can exhibit Pt-like ORR performance in alkaline electrolyte [ 156 ]. To date, H, C, P and B are the most common doping elements in Pd-based ORR catalysts. Generally, tensile strain induced by H and B doping is not favorable for ORR. However, ligand effect originated from electron transfer from H or B to Pd overtakes the adverse strain effect on Pd sites in this case. Thus, the overall Pd d-band center shifts down and the corresponding ΔG O decreases, benefiting the ORR activity. The corresponding H [ 157 ] and B [ 39 ] doped Pd catalysts exhibit 5.3 and 35 times higher MA than that of commercial Pt/C in alkaline electrolytes respectively. Moreover, through using advanced imaging techniques, direct observation of H [ 46 ] and B [ 126 ] in these two catalysts can be realized. In addition, when some nonmetals are introduced into the Pd lattice, they may induce a lattice disorder and even result in the amorphous structure. The increased lattice disorder or amorphous structure will bring about abundant unsaturated active sites, which can act as catalytic centers for electrocatalytic reactions. For example, it was reported that P doping would lead to amorphous Pd-P phase [ 90 ]. With the increasing of P content, the crystal structure of Pd became more disordered and eventually turned amorphous. Poon et al. [ 158 ] find that when the atomic concentration of P drops to 11%, the amorphous structure can still be achieved. The amorphous P doped Pd catalysts exhibits over 4.5 times and 2.6 times higher specific and mass activities than Pd/C and Pt/C catalysts, respectively. The enhanced ORR activity is attributed to the abundant defects, kinks and edges in amorphous structures. In addition, some non-metals such as C have been proven to be greatly helpful in improving the stability of Pd based catalysts through strong nonmetal-metal bonds. C atoms can indirectly modulate the electron states of Pd atoms through bonding with the additional metals and simultaneously promote the durability. Zhang and co-workers [ 47 ] successfully prepared interstitial C-doped PdMo bimetallene by the decomposition of glucose (Figs. 16(a) ). The C content is confirmed to be ∼18.74 at% by thermogravimetric analyses. And the Bader charge analysis suggests that due to the large electronegativity difference, Mo and C exhibit a strong interaction, stabilizing the Mo atoms during catalytic process. It is consistent with the DFT calculations, which reveal that the structure of three C atoms occupying the nearest-neighboring octahedral sites of a Mo atom leads to the most negative Mo removal energy (Fig. 16(b)). Therefore, the MA retention of C-doped PdMo/C reaches 59% after 30000 cycles, higher than that of PdMo/C and Pt/C (Fig. 16(c)). Furthermore, the formed Mo–C bond could weaken the adsorption strength of *O and *OH by 0.41 and 0.16 eV respectively. The optimized adsorption energy and accelerated kinetic process for C-doped PdMo bimetallene bring in about 2 times enhancement in MA and SA compared with the undoped PdMo bimetallene catalysts. 7.2 Hydrogen evolution/oxidation reaction Hydrogen energy plays a very important role in the sustainable development of future energy because of its high power density and environmental friendliness [ 159 ]. The two important reactions involved in hydrogen energy recycling in electrocatalysis field are HER and HOR. Hydrogen binding energy (HBE) is generally considered as the only descriptor for HER/HOR activity in acid electrolyte (Fig. 17(a) ). Similar with ORR, there is a volcano relationship between HER activity and HBE on metal surface. When the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) is 0, the highest HER/HOR activity will be achieved [ 160,161 ]. Under alkaline and neutral conditions, the reaction mechanism is more complex, involving the participation of OH (Fig. 17(b)) [ 162 ]. The doped nonmetals can not only optimize the electronic structure of the PGM active site to achieve ideal ΔG H* value, but also act as additional H or OH adsorption sites, contributing to the accelerated reaction kinetics. In the following section, we will summarize recent studies about nonmetal doped catalysts for HER/HOR (Table 3 ). Among all the metal catalysts, Pt is regarded as the best monometallic HER/HOR catalyst and can still be further optimized through nonmetal doping. A recent study on atomic level P doped Pt nanodendrites (PtP NDs) shows that after introducing P atoms, electrons would transfer from Pt to P [ 85 ]. The resulting negatively charged P atoms can effectively capture protons in acidic environments. Since the atomic radius of P is smaller than that of Pt, the atomic distance between adjacent P and Pt atoms decreases. Therefore, the generated P-Hads (the ads subscript represents adsorption state) can more quickly react with adsorbed hydrogen on adjacent Pt sites to obtain molecular hydrogen, facilitating the reaction kinetics (Fig. 18(a) ). In addition, the adsorption between positively charged Pt sites and H is weakened, promoting the escape of H2 on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the PtP NDs with 0.84% of doped P demonstrate a small overpotential of 13.3 mV at 10 mA cm–2 (η 10 = 13.3 mV) (Fig. 18(b)). The HER/HOR activity on Pd is much lower than Pt (more than 30 times lower) as a result of the strong Pd–H bonding. However, the strong intermediate affinity on Pd catalysts can be addressed via various strategies, leading to enhance HER activity. B doping is proven to weaken the adsorption strength of H on Pd and balance the adsorption energy of H and OH through electron interaction [ 36 ] (Fig. 19(a) ). Therefore, Pd catalyst doped with B exhibits superior HER and HOR activity compared to pure Pd in alkaline environments. Similar to B, the H atoms doping can also optimize the electronic structure of Pd surface atoms and weaken the adsorption of H*, resulting in an excellent HER performance. The corresponding catalysts are called PdH x [ 141 ]. Moreover, the addition of other metals to form binary and/or multimetallic alloy hydrides could further modify the d-band center of Pd and bring brilliant HER performance. For example, Wang et al. [ 49 ] prepared IrPdH nanodendrites via ethanol decomposition process. In HER test, the η 10 of ultrafine IrPdH nanodendrites are 14, 15 and 60 mV at in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4, 1 mol L–1 KOH and 1 mol L–1 PBS electrolytes, respectively, which are superior to the undoped IrPd and commercial Pt/C. DFT calculations reveal that the introduction of H atoms in IrPdH (111) causes the obvious charge redistribution between Ir and Pd sites, which enhances the electronic density of Pd sites (Fig. 19(b)) and results in the downshift of ε d. Apart from modifying the electronic structure of Pd, nonmetal doped Pd catalysts can also serve as core to regulate the catalytic property of shell in core/shell materials. For instance, Jin et al. [ 163 ] prepared Pd/Pt core/shell nanocubes, where tunable lattice strain on thin Pt shells was achieved by optimizing the phosphorization degrees of P doped Pd (Pd-P) cores. Specially, amorphous Pd-P gradually replaces the Pd cores and thus creates further tensile strain on Pt shells along with the phosphorization progresses. On the contrary, compressive strain is generated by controlling the dephosphorization degree of the Pd-P core (Fig. 19(c)). As a result, the author can systematically study the effect of strains on the alkaline HER activity. They find that the strain and HER activity display a volcano relationship (Fig. 19(d)). The best catalyst is obtained at a tensile strain of 2.8%, with about 12.3 and 4.4 times greater SA and MA than those of Pt/C, respectively. DFT calculations reveal that the increase of tensile strain facilitates water dissociation and strengthens the adsorption of *OH and H*. However, compressive strain has the opposite effect. The balance of adsorption of *OH and H* accounts for the volcano curves. Due to the lower price and suitable metal hydrogen bonding energy, ruthenium (Ru, 460 USD per ounce) is one of the most potential substitutes for Pt metal (1023 USD per ounce) [ 164 ]. Modulating Ru electronic structure and leading to a downshift d-band center to weaken the adsorption of H are proved to be an effective way to improve the HER/HOR activity of Ru-based catalysts. Zhao et al. [ 40 ] reported that the doped P changed the electronic structure of Ru by strong electron interactions between Ru and P. The Ru site in P doped Ru catalysts hold the optimized ΔG H* (Fig. 20(a) ). And its rate determining step of HOR is turned from water formation step to the water desorption step with the energy barrier decreases to 0.19 eV after P doping (Fig. 20(b)), resulting in significantly enhanced HER and HOR performance in alkaline electrolytes (η 10 = 33 mV and normalized exchange current density is 5 times higher than that of Ru/C). In addition to ligand effect, the doped nonmetals can further serve as the strong adsorption sites for the *OH intermediate in alkaline solution. Recently, a report demonstrate that the B sites of the B doped Ru (002) surface have a more negative free energy for the adsorption of *OH (–1.67 eV) than that of Ru sites in Ru (002) with (–0.83 eV) and without B doping (–1.44 eV) (Fig. 20(c)) [ 76 ]. Combined with the optimized adsorption of *H in Ru sites (Fig. 20(d)), B doped Ru@carbon nanotube (CNT) exhibits excellent HER activity. 7.3 Electrooxidation of liquid small molecules Liquid small molecule oxidation reactions such as methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR), and ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) are of vital importance for the enhanced performance of direct liquid fuel cells (DLFCs) [ 166 ]. However, the oxidation of most liquid fuels will produce carbon monoxides and other by-products during the electrocatalytic process, which are easily adsorbed on the surface of precious metals, leading to catalyst poisoning and the overall performance degradation of the cell. In addition, the oxidation reaction of liquid small molecules involves multi-step proton transfer and a variety of different reaction intermediates, greatly slowing down its kinetics. In order to accelerate the development of DLFCs, it is necessary to develop catalysts with high activity and toxicity tolerance. It is reported that the strong adsorption of *OH with nonmetals can promote the removal of toxic intermediates by the synergistic effect (Fig. 21 ) [ 44,167 ]. Besides, nonmetals can also modulate the electronic structure of active sites in the PGM surface, enhancing the adsorption of ideal intermediates but weaken the adsorption of some unfavorable intermediates, such as *CO [ 168 ]. Therefore, introducing nonmetals into the lattice of PGMs will be an effective strategy to enhance their activity for the oxidation of liquid molecules. In the following section. We will introduce some recent progress on the enhanced liquid molecule oxidation reaction by nonmetal doped catalysts (Table 4 ). Pt is currently the most efficient monometallic catalyst for methanol electrocatalytic oxidation [ 169 ]. Unfortunately, Pt is highly susceptible to CO poisoning. When the fuel contains 0.001% CO, it can cause significant poisoning and reduce cell performance. The sluggish kinetics for MOR is mainly due to the strong adsorption of the generated CO intermediates on the Pt surface during the oxidation process, which leads to catalyst poisoning. Therefore, improving the anti-poisoning ability of Pt is very important for improving its activity and promoting its practical application. Cheng et al. [ 72 ] implemented a series of nonmetallic surface anions (such as P, S, and Se) to modify the Pt surface and proposed that P can feedback electrons from the p-orbitals to the unoccupied d-orbitals of Pt atoms. The Pt d-band will display downshifting of center location and thus reduce the overlap degree with CO 2π*, thereby demonstrating more than 10-fold enhancement of CO tolerance (only 8.4% decay) than commercial Pt/C. The doping of P is also proved to enable PtNi concave cubes to obtain surface oxygen-containing species such as P-OH at lower potentials, resulting in the enhanced MOR activity of Pt through synergistic effect [ 88 ]. In the presence of P, the Pt site mainly undergoes the adsorption of methanol, activation of C–H bonds and deprotonation processes, while the P site mainly undergoes the adsorption and dissociation of water. As shown in Fig. 22(a) , the band at ~2080 and 1840 cm–1 related to the *CO signal decrease quickly with increasing potential, suggesting the fast removal of *CO species. Therefore, the P-PtNi CNC have an onset potential of 0.38 V for CO stripping, much lower than PtNi CNC and commercial Pt/C. Due to the presence of OH species and the fast removal of *CO species, the P-PtNi CNC exhibits 8.19 times higher specific activity than commercial Pt/C (Fig. 22(b)). In addition to the synergistic effect, non-metal involving approach has also been adopted as effective method to modulate the electronic structure or surface strain of Pt. Liu et al. [ 170 ] employed PdH0.45 as core and deposit a thin Pt shell, where the interstitial H will enlarge the Pd lattice and induce a certain tensile strain over Pt shell (Fig. 22(c)). The obtained PdH0.43@Pt core-shell cubic NPs exhibits a high MA of 32.51 A mgPt –1 for MOR, 41.15 and 3.5 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C and Pd@Pt catalyst (Fig. 22(d)). Moreover, they maintain MA of 4.47 A mgPt –1 after testing for 4000 s, showing excellent stability (Fig. 22(e)). DFT calculations suggest that an appropriate tensile strain significantly strengthens the Pt–OH bonding on (100) facets. While it has much less effect on the binding of CO, evidenced by the nearly unchanged adsorption free energies of CO among these three catalysts. The enhanced OH adsorption would accelerate the oxidation of *CO, accounting for the observed high MOR activity and stability. However, although PdH0.43@Pt performs well in half-cells, its performance in methanol fuel cells is not investigated. Pd has similar electronic structure to Pt and shows more excellent formic acid oxidation performance [ 171 ]. However, in the process of formic acid oxidation, other intermediate products such as *CO and *OH are more easily adsorbed on Pd, leading to the inferior stability of Pd-based catalysts. Studt et al. [ 172 ] indicated that the chemical adsorption energy of carbon bound intermediates (*COOH and *CO) decreased with the increase of octahedral underground B coverage, while that of oxygen bound intermediates (HCOO* and *OH) exhibited the opposite tendency. The low coverage of toxic *CO and *COOH substances on boron doped Pd leaves more free sites on the catalyst surface. It is also examined by the shallower free-energy wells created by carbon bound intermediates on Pd(B/OSS)0.5 ML than on Pd (111) in the free-energy diagram for three formic acid decomposition pathways (Fig. 22(f)). The low coverage of toxic *CO and *COOH substances on boron doped Pd leaves more free sites on the catalyst surface. Therefore, after doping boron into Pd catalyst, the dehydrogenation rate of formic acid increased by three times compared to pure Pd. This opposite relation for *C- and *O-containing intermediates on B-doped Pd surfaces can be extended to explain the promoted catalytic performance for electrochemical EOR [ 64 ]. It is noteworthy that B doped Pd electrocatalysts still have good catalytic activity in device applications. They can reach a maximum power density of 316 mW cm–2 in the direct formic acid fuel cell [ 130 ]. After 4.5 h of nonstop operation at 0.3 V, the power of B doped Pd electrocatalysts is still 9-fold higher than that of the Pd/C. 8 Conclusions and perspectives Here, we summarize the recent achievements on the development of nonmetal doped PGM-based nanocrystals as advanced electrocatalysts for electrochemical energy devices. The decisive role of nonmetallic elements in governing the electrochemical performance of PGM-based catalysts is highlighted. Compared with undoped counterparts, nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts demonstrate much enhanced activity because of the optimized d-band center and/or additional adsorption sites for reaction intermediates. Moreover, robust nonmetal-metal bonds and/or intense electronic interactions between nonmetal and metal atoms would reduce the dissolution of metal and improve the stability of the nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts. Despite considerable progress has been made on nonmetal doped PGM-based electrocatalysts, challenges and opportunities remain. Therefore, we reveal possible directions in the following section, aiming to provide some inspiration for the further research (Fig. 23 ). (1) Synthesis method: The controllable synthesis of nonmetal doped PGM-based electrocatalysts is still challenging. Due to the strong bonding between metal atoms, incorporating nonmetal atoms into PGMs usually needs high temperature or pressure, which will inevitably lead to particle growth and significant diminish the number of active sites. Thus, mild methods are urgently demanded for the synthesis of highly active nonmetal doped PGM-based electrocatalysts with controllable sizes and morphologies. Moreover, bridging the synthetic approach and equipment between lab and industry is also important for scale-up catalysts production. (2) Mechanism study: Even though traditional theories have already explained the role of non-metals in improving the electrocatalytic performance of PGM-based catalysts to some degree, the dynamic evolutions of geometric and electronic structures during electrocatalytic process are still not clear. More advanced in-situ or even operando characterization techniques combining with theoretical calculations are needed to further illustrate the structure-performance relationship of nonmetal doped PGM-based electrocatalysts. The development of in-situ/operando characterization methods such as in-situ synchrotron radiation, surface enhanced Raman spectra would help reveal the actual active sites and guide the design of high-performance nonmetal-doped noble metal catalysts. Extensive calculation models and supporting experimental evidences are also urgently required for the integration of materials genome. (3) New materials and reactions: Developing new catalysts for new electrocatalytic reactions is full of significance. Currently, nonmetal atoms (H, B, P)-doped PGM catalysts, with conventional FCC phase, have been extensively studied for several electrochemical reactions. In the future, one possible research direction is to develop new catalysts with unconventional phase. The atomic arrangement and coordinate environment of active site will be much different from those in conventional FCC phase, which will alter the internal strain and electronic structure to modify the catalytic activity and selectivity. Since the nonmetal atoms possess lower valence electron, smaller atomic radii, introducing these nonmetal atoms into PGM nanoparticles will offer opportunities to prepare unconventional phase, especially under unequilibrium synthetic conditions (high pressure, fast heating/cooling etc.). In addition, PGM-based catalysts doped with ternary or multicomponent nonmetals have attain limited attention compared with binary systems. Efficient utilization of diverse nonmetallic elements is beneficial for achieving more precise and comprehensive regulation of active sites. Moreover, due to the interesting “cocktail effect” and entropy stabilization effect, high entropy alloys have been much focused. Therefore, expanding the composition to more than five elements is an appealing direction. What is more, based on the similarity between electrocatalysis and some other catalysis systems, extending the nonmetal doped PGM-based catalysts to fields such as photocatalysis, enzyme catalysis, and thermal catalysis is also attractive. (4) Stability enhancement: Suppressing the dissolution of the property-enhancing nonmetal elements in the PGM-based electrocatalysts should be highlighted. As mentioned above, the introduction of nonmetal dopants is an efficient pathway to optimize catalytic performance of PGM-based nanoparticles. However, some researchers have already reported that the active nonmetal dopants may depart from the host nanostructure, resulting in the rapid decay of electrocatalytic performance of PGM-based catalysts. Although some methods have been developed to limit nonmetallic effusion, such as morphology control and covering other stable PGM atomic layers on the surface, there is still lack of universal and specific strategies. (5) Performance evaluation in devices: Bridging the gap between half cells and device tests remains challenging. Currently, most of the evaluations for nonmetal-doped noble metal catalysts are conducted in half-cells, the systematical evaluation of the as-obtained catalysts in practical devices is still lacking. At membrane electrode assembly (MEA) level, the catalyst layer displays unique configuration with triple-access (gas-liquid-solid) requirements. Therefore, critical issues such as mass transportation, distribution of ionomers as well as water management cannot be overlooked even though they are usually insignificant under half cell test conditions. Besides, the durability issue of MEA for catalyst is also a great challenge, mainly due to the high voltage and acidic environments at fuel cell operating conditions. Therefore, more attention should be paid on MEA test to meet the practical applications of the catalysts. In conclusion, the incorporation of nonmetal atoms such as H, B, C, N, P and S brings about great opportunities for the design of advanced PGM-based electrocatalysts, benefiting their electrochemical applications in renewable energy devices. We believe that more nonmetals and PGMs will soon be added to the nonmetal doped PGM-based material library with the development of new synthesis and evaluation strategies as well as advanced theoretical calculation and characterization methods. Tanyuan Wang is currently an associate professor of School of Materials Science and Engineering in Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), China. He received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from Peking University in 2015 and worked as a visiting scholar at Stanford University from 2017 to 2018. His research interests are electrocatalysis and nanomaterials synthesis. Qing Li is a professor of School of Materials Science and Engineering in Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), China. He received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from Peking University in 2010 and then worked as a postdoctoral research associate consecutively at Los Alamos National Laboratory (2011–2013) and Brown University (2013–2015). He joined HUST as a full professor in 2016. He has published more than 160 peer-reviewed papers. His research interests include functional nanomaterials and their applications in electrocatalysis, PEM fuel cells and batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts have been well recognized as one of the best catalysts towards energy conversion and storage devices, such as fuel cells and water electrolyzers. Nevertheless, their commercial applications are strictly limited by the unsatisfactory catalytic activity and stability. Recently, nonmetallic (H, B, C, N, P, S, etc.) atoms doping is explored to be an efficient strategy to optimize the catalytic activity and durability of PGM-based catalysts via precisely electronic and coordination structure modulation, thus arising tremendous attention. However, systematical discussions on this topic is still lacking. In this review, the representative progresses of nonmetal elements doped PGM-based electrocatalysts for different electrocatalytic reactions are summarized. Firstly, this review discusses the key factors that affect the activity and stability of the catalysts, and introduces the basic principles of nonmetal-doping for improving the performance of PGM-based catalysts. Secondly, advanced characterization techniques and theoretical calculations are highlighted respectively for revealing the activity enhancement mechanism. Then the synthesis methods to incorporate the nonmetals are listed, intending to provide inspirations for the future design of materials. The promising modification strategies for tuning the active species are further proposed. Afterwards, an overview of nonmetal-doped PGM-based catalysts is provided for the electrocatalytic applications, with an emphasis on revealing the structure-performance relationship. Finally, further developments and challenges involving synthesis, mechanism analysis, new materials as well as reactions, stability issues and practical applications are outlined, aiming to promote the in-depth research on advanced PGM-based catalysts.
